definitions.definition: To sit in judgment on; to pass sentence on (a person or matter).
examples: A higher power will judge you after you are dead.

definitions.definition: To sit in judgment, to act as judge.
examples: Justices in this country judge without appeal.

definitions.definition: To sentence to punishment , to judicially condemn .
examples: He was judged to die for his crimes.

definitions.definition: To form an opinion on; to appraise .
examples: I judge a man’s character by the cut of his suit.

definitions.definition: To constitute a fitting appraisal or criterion of; to provide a basis for forming an opinion on.
To arbitrate ; to pass opinion on something, especially to settle a dispute etc.
examples: We cannot both be right: you must judge between us.

definitions.definition: To have as an opinion; to consider , suppose .
examples: I judge it safe to leave the house once again.

definitions.definition: To form an opinion; to infer .
examples: I judge from the sky that it might rain later.

definitions.definition: To criticize or label another person or thing; to be judgmental toward.
To govern as biblical judge or shophet (over some jurisdiction ).

main_definition: ( transitive ) To sit in judgment on; to pass sentence on (a person or matter).
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive ) To sit in judgment, to act as judge.
( transitive ) To judicially rule or determine .
( transitive , obsolete ) To sentence to punishment , to judicially condemn .
( transitive , obsolete ) To award judicially ; to adjudge .
( transitive ) To form an opinion on; to appraise .
( transitive , obsolete ) To constitute a fitting appraisal or criterion of; to provide a basis for forming an opinion on.
( intransitive ) To arbitrate ; to pass opinion on something, especially to settle a dispute etc.
( transitive ) To have as an opinion; to consider , suppose .
( ambitransitive ) To form an opinion; to infer .
( ambitransitive ) To criticize or label another person or thing; to be judgmental toward.
( ambitransitive ) To govern as biblical judge or shophet (over some jurisdiction ).
